Hellmut Eckert

Bolsista de Produtividade em Pesquisa do CNPq - Nível 1A

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7357691451348243
  • Última atualização do currículo em 18/06/2019

Professor Eckert graduated (Diplomchemiker, 1978) and obtained his PhD (Dr. rer. nat., 1982) in Physical Chemistry at the Westfälische Wilhelms Universität Münster (WWU). He was a professor of Chemistry at the University of California, Santa Barbara 1987-1996), before he accepted a Chair (C-4) in Physical Chemistry at the WWU Münster. He is the founder and chairman of the NRW Graduate School of Chemistry, established at the WWU in 2001. He has published more than 500 papers in the area of solid state NMR technique development and applications in Materials Sciences and has led about 70 Graduate students to their doctoral degrees in Physical Chemistry. He currently advises a group of 9 graduate students and postdocs conducting research in this area. He is one of the founding editors of the Elsevier-Journal Solid State Nuclear Magnetic Resonance and served as Editor-in-Chief from 2010 to 2017. He was an Associate Editor for the ACS journal Chemistry of Materials from 1998-2011. Since 2006 he is member of the Northrhine Westphalian Academy of Sciences, He serves on the selection committees of Georg-Forster postdoctoral programme and the Georg-Forster prize of the Alexander-von-Humboldt Foundation and of the joint Humboldt/CAPES postdoctoral programme. In 2011 he became a faculty member of the Instituto de Física de São Carlos, IFSC/USP. He serves as the Vice Coordinator of the "Center of Research, Technology, and Education in Vitrous Materials (CeRTEV), awarded within the CEPID program of FAPESP. In 2016 he was awarded the George Morey Prize from the American Ceramic Society. Since 2018 he serves on the FAPESP Board of Coordinators in Physics. (Texto informado pelo autor)

2012 - Atual
Structure property correlation in luminescent rare earth doped glasses and ceramics
Descrição: The development of new solid state laser hosts for high optical quality rare-earth ion doped crystals, glasses, and ceramics is an active area of current materials research. To facilitate the design of materials with optimized emission properties, detailed structural information at the atomic level is essential, regarding the local bonding environment (siting) of the rare earth ions, their second-nearest coordination spheres, and their extent of local clustering, as well as the distribution over separate micro- or nanophases in composite materials. In this project, solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) will be used to seek a fundamental understanding of the spectroscopic and photophysical properties of such material systems on a structural basis. The systems to be studied are rare earth containing aluminophosphate, oxyfluoride and fluorophosphate glasses, with systematic variation of host composition, as well as ion species and concentration. In addition sol-gel derived guest-host systems will be examined. Because of their inherent atomic paramagnetism the fluorescent rare-earth species themselves are not accessible to solid state NMR investigations. Thus the NMR strategy for obtaining structural information is based on a three-fold approach: 1) the NMR spectra of the probe nuclei 45Sc and 89Y associated with diamagnetic ?mimics? of the fluorescent species will be analyzed, 2) the effect of paramagnetic doping on the NMR signals of constituent nuclei in the glass or ceramic framework will be examined, and 3) pulsed EPR techniques will be used to characterize the electron spin echo envelope modulation produced by the interactions of the rare-earth ions with the surrounding nuclear magnetic moments. The structural information obtained by these approaches and its correlation with the photophysical properties of these materials will be important for developing new design strategies for high power laser systems and other o.
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Hellmut Eckert - Coordenador.

Projetos de pesquisa


Outras informações relevantes

 
* Although not individually listed, I have taken part in approximately 200 doctoral examinations (UCSB, WWU, USP) and participated in the evaluation of 10 external doctoral theses.
* I have also advised ca. 45 Scientific Induction of Undergraduate Students at UCSB and WWU.
* Since 1987 I have taught several courses, in various occasions, for Undergraduate and Graduate students. Some examples are: General Chemistry, Analytic Chemistry, Physical Inorganic Chemistry, Physical Chemistry Laboratory, Physical Chemistry for High School Teacher Candidates, Introduction to Quantum Mechanics, Advanced Spectroscopic Techniques, Fundamentals of NMR Spectroscopy, Topics in NMR Spectroscopy, Solid State Chemistry and Material Sciences, etc.
* Since 1995 I have taken part in several External Program Review Boards, mostly in Germany, but also in other countries, and I have served as Referee for 9 Habilitation Theses, 7 competitive Senior Faculty recruitments and 31 Faculty Promotion cases, in various countries.
* My network of effective international scientific research cooperation includes more than 50 researchers/groups on all of the continents except Australia and Africa. I have also had or still have Industrial Cooperations with: Glaswerke Schott, Corning Glassworks, Nippon Electric Glass, BASF, Nestle, Ivoclar, Volkswagen, Degussa and Chemmetall.
* Besides the Research Projects listed above, my research group has also received research funding from: DAAD PROBAL (2005 - 2007, EU$ 24.000); Fonds der Chemischen Industrie research stipends (1999 - 2013, EU$ 250.000) and supplies (1999-2008, EU$ 50.000); Schott Glass (2004, EU$ 5.000); Hexal (2003, EU$ 2.800); BASF (2004, EU$ 1.300); Nestle (2003, EU$ 4.000); Ivoclar (2008, EU$ 9.000) and others.
*I am on a permanent leave of absence from the University of Munster, since 2011 until retirement, but maintain my association with that University
